name: K2-133
scenarioDescription:
The K2-133 Exoplanetary System

K2-133 is a star with 0.46 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.46 times its radius. It is located 245.27 light years away from the solar system.

K2-133 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

K2-133 b

K2-133 b was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.07 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-133.

The mass of K2-133 b is 1.96 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-133 b is 1.34 that of Earth. At 1.96 Earth masses, K2-133 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

K2-133 c

K2-133 c was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.87 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-133.

The mass of K2-133 c is 2.99 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-133 c is 1.603 that of Earth. At 2.99 Earth masses, K2-133 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

K2-133 d

K2-133 d was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 11.02 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-133.

The mass of K2-133 d is 5.12 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-133 d is 2.003 that of Earth. At 5.12 Earth masses, K2-133 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

K2-133 e

K2-133 e was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2019-05. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 26.58 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-133.

The mass of K2-133 e is 3.57 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-133 e is 1.73 that of Earth. At 3.57 Earth masses, K2-133 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-133, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by K2.
